case_name: Appellant v. State Transport Corporation, Gujarat

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 757 of 1964 was filed as an appeal by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil APPEAL No. 757 of 1964. Appeal by Special Leave from the Judgment and Order, dated the 28th May, 196

facts.text: Appeal is from the judgment and order dated 28th May 1963 of Gujarat High Court in Special Civil Application No. 419 of 1963.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by Special Leave from the Judgment and Order, dated the 28th May, 1963 of the Gujarat High Court in Special Civil Application No. 419 of 1963. Gopalakrishnan, for the appellant.

facts.text: Gujarat High Court dismissed the application in limine on May 28, 1963.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal, by special leave, is against the judgment and order of the High Court of Gujarat at Ahmedabad, dated May 28, 1963, dismissing in limine an application filed by the appellant under Art. 226 of the Constitution.

facts.text: Appellant was a permanent employee of the State Transport Corporation, Gujarat.

anchor.surface_text: The facts material for the purposes of this appeal may be briefly stated. Me appellant was a permanent employee of the State Transport Corporation, Gujarat, hereinafter referred to as the Corporation.

facts.text: Appellant was employed as a Writer in the Visnagar Depot of the Corporation in Mehsana District.

anchor.surface_text: At the material time he was employed as a Writer in the Visnagar Depot of the Corporation in Mahasana District.

facts.text: On January 15, 1962, appellant applied to Divisional Controller, State Transport, Mehsana, for 15 days leave for personal work.

anchor.surface_text: On January 15, 1962, the appellant applied to the Divisional Controller, State Transport, Mahasana, for leave for 15 days on the ground that he had to attend to his personal work.

facts.text: On January 16, 1962, appellant was transferred from Visnagar to Ambaji where there was a vacancy.

anchor.surface_text: On January 16, 1962, he was transferred from Visnagar to Ambaji where there was a vacancy in the office of the Depot Manager.

facts.text: On January 31, 1962, formal order transferring appellant from Visnagar to Ambaji was passed, directing him to join duty at Ambaji.

anchor.surface_text: On January 31, 1962, a formal order transferring the appellant from Visnagar to Ambaji was passed, and he was directed to join duty at Ambaji.

facts.text: On January 31, 1962, appellant applied for extension of leave on medical grounds.

anchor.surface_text: On that date, the appellant applied for extension of leave on medical grounds but his request was refused by an order, dated February 15, 1962.

facts.text: Appellant's request for extension refused by order dated February 15, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: but his request was refused by an order, dated February 15, 1962. He was directed to report for duty at Ambaji within 48 hours of the receipt of numberice failing which,

facts.text: Appellant directed to report for duty at Ambaji within 48 hours of receipt of notice, failing which removed from service.

anchor.surface_text: He was directed to report for duty at Ambaji within 48 hours of the receipt of numberice failing which, he was warned, he would be removed from service.

facts.text: On March 3, 1962, appellant wrote to Divisional Controller intimating inability to join duty as still not well, enclosed medical certificate.

anchor.surface_text: On March 3, 1962, the appellant wrote a letter to the Divisional Controller intimating him of his inability to join duty as he was still number well. To this letter, he enclosed a medical certificate.

facts.text: By order dated March 9, 1962, services of appellant terminated with effect from January 16, 1962, on ground of long absence.

anchor.surface_text: By an order, dated March 9, 1962, the services of the appellant were terminated with effect from January 16, 1962, on the ground of long absence.

facts.text: On March 17, 1962, appellant made representation to Divisional Controller.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant made a representation to the Divisional Controller on March 17, 1962 and thereafter preferred an appeal to the General Manager of the Corporation.

facts.text: Representation and appeal to General Manager rejected.

anchor.surface_text: Both of them were rejected. A further appeal preferred by him to the L9SUPCI/66--4 4 2 appellate Committee was also unsuccessful.

facts.text: Appeal to Appellate Committee unsuccessful; Committee held leave applications made to evade joining duty at Ambaji.

anchor.surface_text: The Committee held that the leave applications of the appellant were made only with a view to evade joining duty at Ambaji.

facts.text: Appellant applied to Gujarat High Court under Arts. 226 and 227, impleading Divisional Controller as respondent, for writ of certiorari to quash dismissal order.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant applied to the High Court of Gujarat under Arts. 226 and 227 of the Constitution, impleading the Divisional Controller as respondent, for the issue of a writ of certriorari to quash the order of dismissal.

facts.text: High Court petition dismissed in limine on May 28, 1963.

anchor.surface_text: His petition was dismissed in limine on May 28, 1963.

facts.text: On June 17, 1963, appellant applied for certificate to appeal to Supreme Court, refused.

anchor.surface_text: On June 17, 1963, the appellant applied for a certificate to appeal to this Court but it was refused.

facts.text: Special leave granted by Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter he applied for special leave and that was granted by this Court.

facts.text: Respondent is autonomous statutory Corporation under Road Transport Corporations Act, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: It may be stated at the outset that the respondent is an autonomous statutory Corporation formed under the provisions of the Road Transport Corporations Act, 1950.

facts.text: Not disputed that appellant could not invoke Art. 311 of Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: It is number disputed that the appellant companyld number invoke the provisions of Art. 311 of the Constitution.

facts.text: No charge was framed against appellant.

anchor.surface_text: It is admitted that numbercharge was framed against him number was he given an opportunity to show cause.

facts.text: Appellant not given opportunity to show cause.

anchor.surface_text: It is admitted that numbercharge was framed against him number was he given an opportunity to show cause.

facts.text: Termination order referred to long absence as cause.

anchor.surface_text: It is companytended for the respondent that though the order of termination referred to long absence as the cause of termination,

facts.text: Appellant entitled to two months pay in lieu of notice under regulation No. 61.

anchor.surface_text: the termination itself was number by way of punishment and the only right of the appellant was to two months pay in lieu of numberice under regulation No. 61,

facts.text: Regulations govern service conditions of Corporation employees.

anchor.surface_text: We may, at this stage, read the relevant regulations which admittedly govern the service companyditions of the employees of the G Corporation.

facts.text: Supreme Court quashed the order of termination as bad in law, contravening cl. 4(b) and natural justice.

anchor.surface_text: In our judgment the appellant was entitled to an opportunity to show cause against the action proposed to be taken against him. The order of termination passed against the appellant is bad in law since it companytravenes the provisions of cl. 4 b  of the Regulation and also the principles of natural justice.

facts.text: Writ of certiorari issued quashing dismissal order.

anchor.surface_text: In all the circumstances of the case, we are satisfied that the impugned order must be quashed. A writ of certiorari will accordingly issue quashing the order of dismissal,

facts.text: Respondent not precluded from fresh enquiry after giving opportunity under cl. 4(b).

anchor.surface_text: but this will number preclude the respondent from making a fresh enquiry against the appellant after giving him reasonable opportunity to show cause as provided under cl. 4 b  of the regulations.

issues.text: whether the appellant was entitled to an opportunity to show cause against the proposed punishment as required by regulation No. 61 of the Regulations which govern the service conditions of the employees of the Corporation

anchor.surface_text: The short question for determination in the appeal is whether the appellant was entitled to an opportunity to show cause against the proposed punishment as required by regulation No. 61 of the Regulations which govern the service conditions of the employees of the Corporation.

issues.text: whether the termination was by way of punishment requiring compliance with clause 4(b) of Schedule A to the Regulations

anchor.surface_text: 4 b . A person against whom action is proposed to be taken for any act of misconduct, shall be provided with a copy of the charge or charges as well as a statement of allegations that have been made against him, and over which enquiry is being held. Clause 3 defines two classes of offences named acts of misconduct and minor lapses and delinquencies, respectively and sub cl. ii of cl. 3 states inter alia that the misconducts are those specified in Schedule A.

issues.text: whether there was compliance with the principles of natural justice

anchor.surface_text: principles of natural justice. In all the circumstances of the case, we are satisfied that the impugned order must be quashed. A writ of certiorari will accordingly issue quashing the order of dismissal, but this will not preclude the respondent from making a fresh enquiry

arguments.claim: the termination itself was not by way of punishment and the only right of the appellant was to two months pay in lieu of notice under regulation No. 61

anchor.surface_text: It is contended for the respondent that though the order of termination referred to long absence as the cause of termination, the termination itself was not by way of punishment and the only right of the appellant was to two months pay in lieu of notice under regulation No. 61,

court_response_anchor.surface_text: s as well as a statement of allegations that have been made against him, and over which enquiry is being held. Clause 3 defines two classes of offence

arguments.court_reasoning: Long absence constitutes misconduct under clauses 38, 40 and Schedule A requiring procedure under cl. 4(b), not mere reg. 61 termination

arguments.claim: assuming that the termination was by way of punishment, the appellant had been given an opportunity to show cause as evident from the correspondence and circumstances

anchor.surface_text: that assuming that the termination was by way of punishment, the appellant, as would be evident from the correspondence and the circumstances of the case, had been given an opportunity to show cause and that there was in fact and in substance compliance with the rules of natural justice.

arguments.court_reasoning: No charge framed nor any enquiry conducted; no copy of charges or statement of allegations provided

anchor.surface_text: and that there was in fact and in substance compliance with the rules of natural justice. We may, at this stage, read the relevant regulations which admittedly govern the service conditions of the employees of the G Corporation.

arguments.court_reasoning: Order contravenes principles of natural justice as no opportunity to show cause against proposed action

arguments.claim: irregular attendance, absence without leave without reasonable cause, and failure to report for duty when leave refused amount to acts of misconduct under clauses 38, 40 and Schedule A

anchor.surface_text: Regulations 38 and 40 provide that irregular attendance, absence without leave and without reasonable cause and failure, without sufficient cause, to report, when directed, for duty amount to acts of misconduct. Clause 4 b is specific and clear.

arguments.claim: under cl. 4(b), it is obligatory to provide copy of charge/charges and statement of allegations and give reasonable opportunity to show cause before action for misconduct

anchor.surface_text: 4 b . A person against whom action is proposed to be taken for any act of misconduct, shall be provided with a copy of the charge or charges as well as a statement of allegations that have been made against him, and over which enquiry is being held. Clause 3 defines two classes of offences named acts of misconduct

arguments.claim: automatic removal from service without giving reasonable opportunity to show cause why he be not removed is not permitted even for absence without leave

anchor.surface_text: It is true that the respondent may visit the punishment of discharge or removal from service on a person who has absented himself without leave and without reasonable cause, but this cannot entail automatic removal from service without giving such person reasonable opportunity to show cause why he be not removed.

arguments.claim: appellant was entitled to an opportunity to show cause against the action proposed; order of termination is bad in law contravening cl. 4(b) and principles of natural justice

anchor.surface_text: In our judgment the appellant was entitled to an opportunity to show cause against the action proposed to be taken against him. The order of termination passed against the appellant is bad in law since it contravenes the provisions of cl. 4 b of the Regulation and also the principles of natural justice.

holdings.text: Regulations 38 and 40 provide that irregular attendance, absence without leave and without reasonable cause and failure, without sufficient cause, to report, when directed, for duty amount to acts of misconduct.

anchor.surface_text: Regulations 38 and 40 provide that irregular attendance, absence without leave and without reasonable cause and failure, without sufficient cause, to report, when directed, for duty amount to acts of misconduct. Clause 4 b  is specific and clear.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct textual reading of regulations classifying such absences as misconduct under Schedule A as per cl. 3.

holdings.text: Under clause 4(b), it is obligatory to provide a copy of the charge or charges as well as a statement of allegations and give reasonable opportunity to show cause before taking action for any act of misconduct.

anchor.surface_text: 4 b . A person against whom action is proposed to be taken for any act of misconduct, shall be provided with a copy of the charge or charges as well as a statement of allegations that have been made against him, and over which enquiry is being held. Clause 3 defines two classes of offences named acts of misconduct

holdings.reasoning_summary: Plain language of cl. 4(b) read with definition in cl. 3 requiring procedure for misconduct actions.

holdings.text: Automatic removal from service without giving reasonable opportunity to show cause is not permitted even for absence without leave and without reasonable cause.

anchor.surface_text: It is true that the respondent may visit the punishment of discharge or removal from service on a person who has absented himself without leave and without reasonable cause, but this cannot entail automatic removal from service without giving such person reasonable opportunity to show cause why he be not removed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Punishment for misconduct cannot bypass mandatory procedural safeguards in cl. 4(b) despite nature of default.

holdings.text: The appellant was entitled to an opportunity to show cause against the action proposed to be taken against him.

anchor.surface_text: In our judgment the appellant was entitled to an opportunity to show cause against the action proposed to be taken against him. The order of termination passed against the appellant is bad in law since it contravenes the provisions of cl. 4 b  of the Regulation

holdings.reasoning_summary: Application of cl. 4(b) to facts of prolonged unauthorized absence treated as misconduct.

holdings.text: The order of termination passed against the appellant is bad in law since it contravenes the provisions of cl. 4(b) of the Regulation and also the principles of natural justice.

anchor.surface_text: The order of termination passed against the appellant is bad in law since it contravenes the provisions of cl. 4 b  of the Regulation and also the principles of natural justice. In all the circumstances of the case, we are satisfied that the impugned order must be quashed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No charges framed, no enquiry, no opportunity provided despite misconduct allegation violating regulation and natural justice.

holdings.text: The impugned order must be quashed. A writ of certiorari will accordingly issue quashing the order of dismissal.

anchor.surface_text: In all the circumstances of the case, we are satisfied that the impugned order must be quashed. A writ of certiorari will accordingly issue quashing the order of dismissal, but this will not preclude the respondent from making a fresh enquiry

holdings.reasoning_summary: Procedural infirmities render order void; appropriate writ remedy under Art. 226/227 upheld on appeal.

holdings.text: This will not preclude the respondent from making a fresh enquiry against the appellant after giving him reasonable opportunity to show cause as provided under cl. 4(b) of the regulations.

anchor.surface_text: but this will not preclude the respondent from making a fresh enquiry against the appellant after giving him reasonable opportunity to show cause as provided under cl. 4 b  of the regulations.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Quashing does not bar curative proceedings compliant with due process.

anchor.surface_text: It is true that the respondent may visit the punishment of discharge or removal from service on a person who has absented himself without leave and without reasonable cause, but this cannot entail automatic removal from service without giving such person reasonable opportunity to show cause why he be not removed.

In all the circumstances of the case, we are satisfied that the impugned order must be quashed. A writ of certiorari will accordingly issue quashing the order of dismissal, but this will number preclude the respondent from making a fresh enquiry against the appellant after giving him reasonable opportunity to show cause as provided under cl. 4 b
